user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarCreate_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarCreate_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, uint32 options)
{
    int32                              final_status;
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    final_status = OS_SUCCESS;
    impl         = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    /*
    ** create the underlying mutex
    */
    status = pthread_mutex_init(&impl->mut, NULL);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        OS_DEBUG("Error: CondVar mutex could not be created. ID = %lu: %s\n",
                 OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(status));
        final_status = OS_ERROR;
    }
    else
    {
        /*
        ** create the condvar
        */
        status = pthread_cond_init(&impl->cv, NULL);
        if (status != 0)
        {
            pthread_mutex_destroy(&impl->mut);

            OS_DEBUG("Error: CondVar could not be created. ID = %lu: %s\n",
                     OS_ObjectIdToInteger(OS_ObjectIdFromToken(token)), strerror(status));
            final_status = OS_ERROR;
        }
    }

    return final_status;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarCreate_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[OS_MAX_CONDVARS]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mut;
    pthread_cond_t  cv;
} OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t
...
static inline osal_id_t OS_ObjectIdFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_id;
}
...
static inline unsigned long OS_ObjectIdToInteger(osal_id_t object_id)
{
#ifdef OSAL_OMIT_DEPRECATED
    return object_id.v;
#else
    return object_id;
#endif
}
...
#define OS_DEBUG(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the provided function and related definitions for any use of the Standard Library function memcmp or any use of memcmp to compare null-terminated strings. No call to memcmp appears in the target function or the supplied supporting code. There are no indirect uses of memcmp via macros or helpers in the shown code. The code uses strerror (to obtain an error message string) and pthread APIs, but these are not comparisons of null-terminated strings via memcmp. Therefore there are no code fragments in the provided code that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14.
